CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Elinor Sutherland (later EG) was born in Jersey (one of the Channel Islands), three months before her father died of typhoid in Italy.

P.BIRTHPOSITION: Her sister, Lucy Christiana, who was two years older, became a famous couturière under the name of Lucile, later Lady Duff Gordon). 3 under Lucy Christiana Duff Gordon

SHORTPROSE.P: EG, though born in the Channel Islands, was descended on both sides from recent immigrants to Canada. Her maternal grandparents brought her a mixed heritage (he being Anglo-French and she Irish). In Canada from about the mid nineteenth century, they prospered as farmers and land-owners. EG's father, who had emigrated to Canada from Scotland, seems to have been a modern cosmopolitan ready to settle in any country or continent where there was work that interested him.

EG's maternal grandmother believed in the importance of class distinction, and taught her grand-daughters to value the aristocracy and the aristocratic way of life.3-53 EG's father claimed descent from the Jacobite Dukes of Sutherland and the Earldom of Duffus. Though she was too young when he died to have heard it from his own lips, Elinor believed this claim all her life and, combined with her grandmother's teaching, it led her to build a strong sense of affiliation with the upper social classes. Despite this subjective class status, she grew up in straitened circumstances because of her stepfather's poor investments. In adulthood, EG and her husband were under constant financial strain because he too was a bad manager of money and they both lived beyond their means.4, 616, 3922

Before the age of six, EG had renounced orthodox Christianity; her grandmother had enlisted a clergyman to teach Elinor and her sister the catechism, but both girls rebelled against Christian dogma. 14-15 17 In adulthood, EG experimented with Spiritualism (which she later denounced). She referred to herself as a Protestant, but maintained a deep and devoted belief in reincarnation and in karma. 185

EG's mother, Elinor (Saunders) Sutherland, later Kennedy, was married at nineteen and widowed at twenty-three. For the first six years of Elinor's life she played no active role in her children's upbringing. She remarried when Elinor was seven. 7, 18-19 6

EG's father, Douglas Sutherland, was a Scots-Canadian civil engineer. He played the violin, wrote poetry, and spoke a number of languages. Shortly after he married EG's mother they moved to New York, but when the American Civil War broke out he took a post in Brazil. When his contract expired he moved to England with his wife.6-94-6 He contracted a fatal case of typhoid while he was working on a contract at Turin in Italy, and he died on 30 January 1865 while Elinor was a baby. His death left his widow in dire financial straits.6-7

EG's maternal grandparents, particularly her grandmother, played a large role in her upbringing. Her grandmother, a severe, proud, and conservative matriarch, taught Elinor self-control by making her sit still and silent for long periods of time. Elinor greatly admired her grandmother, who taught her to respect and rely on hierarchical institutions and systems.1214-15

In 1884 EG's sister, Lucy (later Lady Duff Gordon) (having left home at sixteen), married, at about twenty-two, a forty-year-old bachelor named James Wallace.44-5under Lucy Christiana Duff Gordon The marriage quickly ended in divorce.

EG's mother married as her second husband, in 1871, a well-to-do, sixty-three-year-old bachelor, David Kennedy, a neighbour and long-time family friend (he had attended her first wedding). He had pursued her ceaselessly, but once they were married he began to doubt his decision, largely because he had no interest in bringing up two young children (he had been shielded from the girls while he courted their mother). Consequently, young Elinor and her sister saw their stepfather as tyrannical, demanding of their mother's full attention, selfish, domineering, and neglectful. He died in 1890, after having suffered from bronchitis and asthma for years. 18-19 54 under Lucy Christiana Duff Gordon img: I trust odnb for death date tho its given differently elsewhere.

After Elinor's father's early death left the family poor, her mother moved her two infant daughters to her parents' estate at Summerhill, near Guelph, Ontario. They arrived in Canada on 25 August 1865.71028 Later in life, EG wrote that her six years at Summerhill developed my character, moulded my tastes, and coloured my point of view for life.11

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: After the mother of Elinor Sutherland (later EG) married David Kennedy, the new family moved from Canada back to Elinor's birthplace, Jersey in the Channel Islands.20

SHORTPROSE.P:
As a girl, the future EG loved to hear Tennyson's poetry, especially the Idylls of the King (published from 1859), many of which she learned by heart. She also adored George MacDonald's The Princess and the Goblin (1872), which she later described as a book that provided a turning-point in my life, and influenced me more profoundly than any other which I have ever read.14, 1214
EG's biographer Joan Hardwick gives 1856 as the first publication of Idylls of the King, but the four earliest poems in the sequence appeared in June 1859. Elinor became interested in Greek mythology after reading Charles Kingsley's The Heroes (1855), from which she turned to translations of Greek myths.24

As was usual for her time and class, Elinor's mother and stepfather employed a series of governesses to teach her and her sister. In later life Elinor wrote, I cannot remember learning anything of value from any of them, except perhaps from the French master.22 Her other subjects were mathematics, geography, and spelling.

Since she abhorred her governesses, Elinor took her education into her own hands, reading every book she could in the library: Pepys's diary, Cervantes' Don Quixote (an eighteenth-century French version), Scott, Agnes [and Elizabeth] Strickland, Lady Blessington, Byron, and the major French classics.

DIV2.HEADING: Religion: The Greek Pantheon vs Christianity

SHORTPROSE.P: By the age of twelve, EG's reading of Greek myth (in translation) had brought her to believe absolutely in the reality of the Gods and Goddesses of ancient Greece, and in the existence of Pan and his nymphs.24 Conversely, she found the Christianity that she knew puritanical, hypocritical, inhibitive, and repressive. Yet when she looked back as an adult she claimed that I never ceased to believe in the reality and love of Christ. Her refusal of Christianity was a matter of rebelling against institutional doctrines and practices.2538

DIV2.HEADING: The Roots of Romanticism: Educating Herself

SHORTPROSE.P: After Elinor Sutherland (later EG) turned fourteen she no longer had a governess. Eager for intellectual stimulation, she took it upon herself to read everything in her stepfather's book collection, which had recently reached Jersey and to which she had free access. At this stage her reading centred in the eighteenth century: Gibbon's Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire (1776-88), Sterne's A Sentimental Journey (1768), Voltaire's Zadig (1748), La Rochefoucauld's Maxims (1665), and Chesterfield's Letters to his Son (1774). The last two of these became like Bibles to her.364337 She later wrote that she became saturated with Bourbon Court History, and the atmosphere of ancient Rome which I absorbed from Gibbon superposed itself upon my old love of all things Greek.37 When she tired of the books in the library, she visited St Helier's public library to read and memorise passages from the encyclopaedia.3937
During her adolescence EG travelled many times to Paris. Like her contemporary Baroness Orczy she loved its rich history of aristocracy rather than that of revolution.40-1, 47-53

From an early age, EG developed a stubborn belief in a particular kind of romantic love. This, she believed, was the only kind of love worth marrying for; it was the love which, according to her mother, her parents had and her mother and stepfather did not. When in her late teenage years Elinor began to receive marriage proposals, including one from a duke and one from a millionaire, she turned them down because she was not romantically in love with these men. To her commitment to romance she added a realistic sense of the necessity of money: I had no illusions about the joys of love in a cottage, and knew only too well the long struggle and misery of poverty.4651

James Wallace, husband of EG's sister Lucy, gambled and drank their money away. Lucy finally divorced him in 1889; her mother paid for the divorce with the little money that David Kennedy had left her at his death. To provide for herself and her daughter, Lucy established a dressmaking business, launching what was to become a highly successful, international career in fashion design. She opened her first business, Lucile Ltd, at the home she shared with her mother in Davies Street, London. It had expanded so much that by 1895 she needed a larger space, and she re-opened it at 24 Old Burlington Street. Within a few years, Lucy or Lucile was designing and selling dresses to well-known socialites and prominent figures, such as the Princess of Wales, Margot, Lady Asquith, and Lady Desborough. In 1897 Lucy expanded her business again, at the Maison Lucile, 17 Hanover Square. She was by now a well-established couturière, and she promoted her business with cards advertising Picture Frocks and Corsets.58 By the mid-1890s she had taken Sir Cosmo Duff Gordon as a business partner; they married in May 1900.5458, 77, 915760, 85
Sir Cosmo was a nephew by marriage, not a descendant, of translator and letter-writer Lucie Duff Gordon. Lucy's designs, when loosed upon a startled London, a London of flannel underclothes, woollen stockings and voluminous petticoats, shocked her Edwardian customers. They showed the world that a woman's leg can be a thing of beauty, instead of a limb . . . which was only spoken of in the privacy of the fitting-room.73 By the turn of the century she was generating almost £40,000 a year in profits.125

In 1910, after a lavish advertising campaign in the USA, Lucy took fifty new designs with her to New York, where she opened an American branch of her business and began to give private fashion consultations to the wealthy.126-9 In 1912 she set up shop in Paris, in the rue de Penthièvres, and in the same year she and her husband went on the Titanic's maiden voyage. They survived the sinking of the ship, though their names had mistakenly been printed on the list of the dead or missing.176 Lucy's success in America reached a pinnacle in 1917, when Sears Roebuck contracted her to design dresses for their catalogue. But her career was soon to be ended, partly by the effects of the First World War on the London and Paris fashion industry. After the war she tried to initiate a new line of clothes in Paris, but was unsuccessful. Bankrupt in 1923, she returned to England where in 1932 she published her autobiography, Discretions and Indiscretions.212197, 226title-page and prelims She died on 14 April 1935.279

In 1890, after the death of her oppressive stepfather, David Kennedy, Elinor Sutherland (later Glyn) moved with her mother from Jersey to London. With Elinor's sister, Lucy, they rented a house at 25 Davies Street. Kennedy's death and Lucy's divorce left the family in serious financial trouble.5458under Lucy Christiana Duff Gordon

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Elinor Sutherland married Clayton Glyn, a well-established bachelor ten years her senior, at St George's, Hanover Square, already a fashionable church for weddings.

SHORTPROSE.P: Forty years later, Elinor wrote that her relationship with Clayton had the inevitability of Fate from the very start.57 She was attracted to him because I was unconsciously reminded of the illustrations in my books of Cinderella's fairy Prince.57 Elinor's sister made her bridal gown, as well as the dresses for all the bridesmaids.58
Elinor and Clayton Glyn moved into his three-hundred-year-old farmhouse, Sheering Hall, near Harlow in Essex.56, 59

The Glyns enjoyed an active social life, which included shooting parties in Scotland, and masquerades and fancy dress balls in not only in Europe—England, France, Italy—but also in Egypt, where Elinor mixed with English aristocrats and Egyptian nobles. She always put her social life first, taking care to see and be seen at the most fashionable gatherings. She was, says the Dictionary of Literary Biography, an ostentatious fashion plate.153103-4, 12668-9, 75-7

Having been convinced from childhood that she belonged to a superior class although her family was pushed for money, EG continued to suffer from financial instability as an adult. She consistently put up a façade of having more money than she actually did. She prized class status highly, abhorred poverty, and largely ignored its existence as a social problem. In later years she bracketed her confession of shame at her lack of sympathy for the less fortunate with another distancing gesture. I feel ashamed now when I look back at my blindness and my superiority. . . . I had never had occasion to ponder the problem of poverty.61 She asserted that when she lived in Jersey, personal contact with any but one's own class was unknown.61 She cited her adolescent experience in France as confirming her understanding of the dominance of class distinction in the world, and her aversion to the lower classes.61-2

CHRONPROSE.CHILDREN: EG gave birth to her first child, a daughter named Margot (later Lady Davson).

SHORTPROSE.P: EG and her husband exemplified later Victorian upper-class attitudes toward child-rearing: he built a new wing onto Sheering Hall so that the nursery and all its trappings would remain safely distanced from him. Elinor too found that she was not very interested in babies.67 Her mother ended up playing a substantial role in raising EG's two daughters, as Elinor's grandmother had done in Elinor's upbringing.
Margot's son Geoffrey Leo Simon Davson became a writer and assumed the name of Anthony Glyn in honour of his grandmother.
After Margot's birth EG fell ill, first with typhoid fever, then with a concussion sustained when she fell at the theatre in Edinburgh. It took her almost three years to recover fully.86-774
Throughout their marriage, EG and her husband wintered in various warm locations, such as Italy and Egypt.91, 99

EG gave birth to her second daughter (Juliet, later Rhys Williams) on 15 December 1898.78 Juliet grew up to be most unlike her mother: a specialist in economics, politically active and devoted to public service, particularly in social and medical services for pregnant women and children. During the 1930s she acted as treasurer of Queen Charlotte's Hospital Anaesthetic Fund, as secretary for the Joint Council of Midwifery, and as a member of the interdepartmental committee on abortion.under Williams, Dame Juliet Evangeline Rhys She was made a DBE in 1937 for her work on the Midwives' Act of 1936 (which established directives for professional training and a salary scale for midwives working with local government), and was later appointed a dame of grace of the order of St John of Jerusalem.under Williams, Dame Juliet Evangeline Rhys She published two books advocating welfare policies (Something to Look Forward to: A Suggestion for a New Social Contract, 1943, and Family Allowances and Social Security, 1944) as well as other titles both highly specialist (Taxation and Incentive, 1953) and lighter (Aircraftwoman Grey, A Novel, 1943).under Williams, Dame Juliet Evangeline Rhys An active member of the Liberal Party, she chaired the publications and publicity committee of the Women's Liberal Federation. After the war she worked in European reconstruction as secretary of the British committee of the European League of Economic Co-operation. She died in 1964.
After the birth of this second daughter, EG's husband went to Monte Carlo, where he gambled away the large sum of £10,000. His excuse was being distraught that the child was not a male heir.92

Once again, EG fell seriously ill after childbirth, this time with typhoid and rheumatic fever (though the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography suggests she suffered from post-partum depression). Everyone, including herself, thought she was going to die, but at this point, through reading her youthful journals, she discovered a new direction for her life: writing.92

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: EG appeared on stage in a tableau vivant, one of a series designed by a socialite named Lady Arthur Paget (Minnie) and directed by Beerbohm Tree at His Majesty's Theatre.

SCHOLARNOTE.P: EG's grandson biographer, Anthony Glyn, says this performance took place in May 1900.83

SHORTPROSE.P: The other women in these tableaux vivants (all titled except one) were Lady Mary Sackville, the Baroness d'Erlanger, Lady St Oswald, and Winifred Curzon (sister-in-law of EG's future lover). They enacted The Five Senses as painted by Titian.84209

About a year later, EG and her husband were present to see Queen Victoria's body in its triple coffin crossing London on 2 February 1901.97under Queen Victoria I felt that I was witnessing the funeral procession of England's greatness and glory, EG wrote years later in her autobiography.98

Without supporting any political party, EG held conservative political views throughout her life. She opposed the suffrage movement during its struggle, but years later, writing her autobiography with an eye to posterity, she revised her earlier views to see herself as a member of the band of pioneers in the cause of feminine emancipation who laboured so earnestly . . . to free the souls and bodies of women from the heavy age-old trammels of custom and convention.131 During her time in Egypt she became a strong advocate of British Imperialism, whose ideals upheld her notions of autocracy, aristocratic rule, class hierarchies, and Victorian morality. She particularly admired Evelyn Baring, Lord Cromer, the British Consul in Egypt. Her comment in her autobiography—that his sagacious rule ensured not merely the political dominance of the British, but also the maintenance of a stately, dignified, yet gay social life—exemplifies her habit of subordinating the political to the social.10099-101, 13192

EG writes in her autobiography that she experienced her first sense of déjà vu in Pompeii; it was followed by a second experience at the Temple of Neptune at Paestum. After these experiences, she read and thought about reincarnation, and came to the conclusion that I have lived on earth before, probably many times, and that these moments of unusual vision are due to some special . . . sensitiveness to influences from beyond the veil, and are in no sense illusory.112101 For the rest of her life, she experienced from time to time what she believed to be visions of her past lives.110-17 She also developed a theory of her own about karma: it is, she wrote, concerned rather with the adjustment, or re-adjustment, of the relations between one individual and another, than with punishment of any kind.118 She claimed that her reading on reincarnation, pre-existence, and karma helped her to understand and accept the New Testament.119-21

By 1894 EG felt that the romance of her marriage was over. In 1901 or 1902 she fell in love with Major Seymour Wynne Finch.8494-6
EG dates this affair in 1902, while her biographer Joan Hardwick says it took place in 1901.
By 1902 EG was suffering a recurrence of a severe pain in her side that she had first experienced in Egypt. To treat this pain she went to the Bohemian spa of Carlsbad.129

This visit furthered her social networking, bringing her together with the classical scholar, lawyer and judge Sir Francis Henry Jeune (later Lord St Helier) and Lady Jeune, of whom she became a close friend. They introduced her to the writer Sir Gilbert Parker, who also became her friend.96108

In 1903 EG, bored with her marriage, fell for Lord Milner, an imperialist politician who had been the editor of the Pall Mall Gazette and a civil servant in Egypt.111under Alfred Milner The two corresponded for some time, even after Glyn had begun another affair with Lord Alistair Innes-Ker, an army officer. Around this same time (1903-05), she also met and felt attracted to Lord Curzon, a Conservative anti-suffragist, formerly Viceroy of India.113-16 Because of EG's rigid moral code, however, these affairs remained chaste.118

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: EG set out to travel alone for almost a year through the United States (which she had always considered to be God's own Country).

SHORTPROSE.P: Her husband did not travel with her, but took their children and her mother to Ceylon, Japan, and Russia. An American friend of EG's had suggested that she should make the trip and had offered to introduce her to New York society. She revelled in the very big adventure to be thus travelling about by myself, in the rôle of Elinor Glyn the famous authoress, instead of in the company of my husband as the rather timid, peculiar-looking wife of the well-known traveller.138 In her autobiography, thirty years later, EG remembered that her first impression of Americans was that there was a faint look of the Red Indian about most of the people.140 Accordingly she found American civilians to be primitive, though thirty years later in her autobiography she wrote that the American woman is unquestionably the most beautiful, the best-dressed, best-turned-out and consequently the most attractive of all women.151 She particularly enjoyed the western States, because this country and its inhabitants represented romance.158
In the USA EG met Mark Twain, whom she thought the wittiest creature imaginable.144

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: When EG's husband returned from his travels around the world, he confessed to her that he had spent all of their capital and was now in serious debt.

SHORTPROSE.P: He excused himself on the grounds that without a male heir he had found little point in amassing a fortune (his daughters could marry rich men). EG was shocked: though she had written of her husband as a Prince Charming, she also complained that she had imagined him to be a very rich man.169 She paid off some of his debts with money earned by her book sales, and thereafter she controlled the payment of all the household expenses, and the cost of the children's education.169 The family was forced to sell Sheering Hall and to live with EG's mother at Lamberts, a cottage nearby. EG was also forced to sign her marriage settlement away to cover her husband's expenses. Despite the threat of bankruptcy (averted by her literary earnings), both of them continued to live beyond their means, and Elinor faced financial problems throughout her marriage. She later remembered the years from the summer of 1908 to the winter of 1913 . . . as one long nightmare of recurring financial crises.17411078

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: EG played the role of the Lady in a private production adapted from her romance novel Three Weeks at the Adelphi Theatre in London.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Her romantic attraction to Lord Curzon resurfaced when he went out of his way to compliment her on this production. Her previous determination to be faithful to her husband was now weakened by passion and a real conflict between the fidelity she believed she owed her husband and a desire to experience love to the full.148 By now Curzon's wife, Mary, had died.
The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography mentions the deepening of their mutual love during the last years of a marriage which had been painful in its early stages.under Mary Victoria Curzon After a series of secret meetings, the lovers made their affair public. It lasted eight years, during which time EG grew increasingly remote from her husband and their daughters, who were brought up largely by her mother.149-51 Once her husband died, however, Curzon did not propose to her, as she had expected, but to another fashionable society widow, Grace Duggan. Disappointed and angry, EG burned his letters, of which she had nearly five hundred.228

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: At the invitation of the Grand Duchess Cyril (or Kiril) of Russia, EG took up residence in St Petersburg for the winter.

SCHOLARNOTE.P: Biographers Meredith Etherington-Smith and Jeremy Pilcher follow the Old Style in use in Russia when they date EG's arrival there to 18 December.131

SHORTPROSE.P: In St Petersburg she socialised with members of the Russian aristocracy, particularly the Grand Duchess Vladimir, as well as with foreign diplomats and members of foreign nobility.157 Though she spent her entire stay at the Russian court, surrounded by luxury and wealth, she quickly realised the precariousness of Russian life in general: this was a country . . . in which it was very unsafe to know too much, or to hold strong opinions, whether about politics or individuals.198-9

EG's autobiography includes a strange tale of near abduction. During her stay in St Petersburg, she received notice that her husband was in debt again and needed her to return to London immediately. She decided to travel through Moscow and Warsaw en route to London, and a man claiming to be an official of the Russian court told her that all her travel arrangements, including hotels, had been made for her. She believed him and followed his instructions. But when she arrived in Warsaw, another strange man picked her up and drove her off, apparently attempting to abduct her. Polish policemen stopped him, however, and turned the carriage back towards Warsaw. Once there, EG went straight to the station and caught the next train to Germany. She never found out who it was who had conspired to abduct her.188-92159-61
In St Petersburgh EG attended many balls and ceremonial functions; the Russian court greatly impressed her with its grandeur in comparison with the simplicity of the English court.193

One of EG's closest friends was a leading Anglo-American socialite, Minnie, Lady Arthur Paget. She also became a good friend of author and philosopher F. H. Bradley, whom she met in France when they were staying in the same hotel.208, 212170 She claimed that Bradley's book Appearance and Reality (1893) had influenced her greatly, and that he had helped her very much to study the difficult art of thinking clearly.212 EG built another lasting friendship with Theresa, Marchioness of Londonderry, who was an active lobbyist for Conservative policies and a founder-leader of the Ulster Women's Unionist Council. The marchioness came into her own as the presiding genius of tory high society when Andrew Bonar Law became Conservative leader in November 1911, and retained her influence until her husband died in February 1915.under Charles Stewart Vane-Tempest Stewart214
The Ulster Women's Unionist Council, formed on 23 January 1911, was established to oppose Irish Home Rule and campaign for the continuing union of Ireland with England.

From 1913 to 1915, EG lived intermittently in Paris as well as London. She was by now rarely seen with her husband. She later reported Parisian society to be hectic and a little wild: vices and eccentrities were tolerated, reserve was a thing of the past.221213-15 During this time she and her family had no idea of the political turmoil brewing in Europe. In her autobiography EG finds it strange, on looking back, to remember how oddly ignorant we all were of the possibilities of the political situation. The sense of calamity was in the air, but it was quite undefined.222

In 1915 EG travelled back to Paris to join the war effort by writing French propaganda articles for American journals. She also visited wounded English soldiers at the Trianon Palace Hotel in Versailles, which had been turned into a hospital.225-6189, 191

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: EG's husband died after some years of deteriorating health.

SHORTPROSE.P: The horror and tragedy of everything seemed overwhelming, she wrote in her autobiography, twenty-two years later.227
Back in London after her husband's death, EG helped to serve meals to soldiers at Victoria Station as war work. She felt that every soldier seemed a hero.227-8

In 1917, with a renewed contract to write articles on the war for American news agencies, EG returned to Paris. Her contract enabled her to obtain permits to visit the most dangerous areas, and French officers told me that no other woman had been so near to the Front.234 She spent the rest of the war in Paris, becoming so accustomed to air raids that the bursting anti-aircraft shells meant no more than so many fireworks, and all feeling of danger from the raids disappeared, as far as I was concerned.262 What frightened her more than bombs, or the Zeppelins she had experienced in England, was the gunfire she could hear close by at the front: It is a solemn moment when one first hears the sound of guns—guns not firing volleys in honour of some public rejoicing, not exploding empty shells at reviews, but guns deliberately aimed at human beings with the intention to kill.204

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: EG served as vice-president of Secours Franco-Américain, an organisation dedicated to helping war refugees resettle in the recaptured areas.

SHORTPROSE.P: The organisation engaged in fundraising for the resettlement of refugees. In particular, it built temporary refugee huts near Noyon.
Ignoring orders to leave France for her safety, EG instead travelled in 1918 to visit the American base camps at St Nazaire.263, 266208-9190
After the war, EG took a flat in Versailles.269

Thnere she met Liberal Prime Minister David Lloyd George, who helped to engineer the Versailles Peace Treaty. Her staunchly conservative views made it matter for surprise that she found him much smarter [in appearance] than his pictures would suggest.271

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Lord Riddell, who had engaged EG as a special correspondent for his paper, The News of the World, got her a press permit to witness the signing of the Versailles Peace Treaty, in the Hall of Mirrors of the Palace of Versailles.

SHORTPROSE.P: The only other woman to witness the signing was Frances Stevenson, mistress of British Prime Minister David Lloyd George.

In February 1920 EG went to Egypt for a second time. There she enjoyed the company of Lord Milner and attended a number of royal balls and extravagant parties.278-9 Four weeks later she went to Spain, where she attended the Easter festivities at the Spanish court.280218262-4

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: At the behest of the Anglo-Swedish Literary Society, EG gave a series of lectures on education, female emancipation, marriage, and other subjects in Norway, Sweden, and Denmark.

SHORTPROSE.P: She lectured on Woman's Place in Modern Civilization, Marriage Customs, and Discipline. The text of the lectures does not survive.246
She was presented to the King and Queen while in Spain, and to the King while in Denmark (by Lord and Lady Granville).290, 315

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: EG entered the Hollywood film industry, accepting a contract with Jesse Lasky of Famous-Players-Lasky (later Paramount) to study film-writing and to compose film-scripts.

SHORTPROSE.P: To boost her persona as a dignified foreign lady, she called herself Madame Glyn.299-300, 309219-21 In 1921 she produced her first film, The Great Moment, which was directed by Sam Wood and which starred Gloria Swanson.She produced a number of films after this: her second was Beyond the Rocks, starring Rudolph Valentino and Gloria Swanson. This film, which she finished in February 1922, was contracted by Lasky's company. After her contract with Famous-Players-Lasky ended in March 1922, she produced one film for Perfect Pictures (The World's a Stage, 1922) and one for Reliable Feature Film (How to Educate a Wife, 1924). In the meantime, she rejected the terms of Famous-Players-Lasky's second contract offer, as well as an offer from United Artists, signing instead with the newly-formed Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM), which agreed to allow her to participate in directing. She worked for MGM for two years, from 1924 to 1926, producing five films, all adapted from her own novels.153299-300, 309230-4, 242-4under Elinor Glyn222

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: EG (already a Hollywood producer) returned to the USA, where she gave a series of ten-minute lectures in New York on the topic of love in vaudeville. She was paid £500 a week.
On the advice of her son-in-law, Rhys Rhys-Williams (Liberal MP), EG established Elinor Glyn Ltd. Her daughters and their husbands acted as the company's board of directors.

SHORTPROSE.P: Elinor Glyn Ltd was formed to govern her finances, to secure her the copyrights in and royalties from her films, and to help her gain negotiating credibility. As a member of the board, Rhys-Williams went to MGM and successfully renegotiated EG's two-year contract.249 After this contract ended in 1926, she returned to Famous-Players-Lasky (now Paramount), for whom she produced three films.153

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: EG produced and appeared as herself in her film It. Clara Bow played the leading role. Clarence Badger directed the film, which had been designed by Paramount's Benjamin Schulberg.

SHORTPROSE.P: It was a piquant and fashionable term for sex-appeal. After the film's production, EG went on a promotional tour across the USA.263

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: EG had a cameo appearance in director King Vidor's film about Hollywood stars, Show People, which starred Marion Davies.

SHORTPROSE.P: By now her Hollywood career had begun to taper off, as her contract with Paramount expired in this year. She made only one film in the US after 1928: a talkie entitled Such Men are Dangerous, for 20th Century Fox in 1930. EG left the American film industry for good that year.323, 325-6153 Over the course of her Hollywood career, she worked with or directed a number of actors, including Gary Cooper, Milton Sills, Conrad Nagel, Aileen Pringle, Pauline Stark, Eleanor Boardman, Lew Cody, and John Gilbert.248 She particularly enjoyed working with director Alan Crosland, who let her direct scenes on her own and who directed MGM's production of her novel Three Weeks. She also favoured artistic director Cedric Gibbons.248, 250, 263232

During her time in the Hollywood film industry, EG became friendly with such stars as Mary Pickford, Douglas Fairbanks, Charlie Chaplin, and Marion Davies. She stayed with Davies for six weeks in 1928.301, 326234, 237 In November 1924 she joined Chaplin, Louella Parsons, and Thomas Ince, among others, on William Randolph Hearst's yacht. When Ince suddenly died on the trip, his death was at first hushed up and then became a lasting focus of rumours that suggested murder. (A recent film of this episode casts EG as narrator.)under The Cat's Meow

After leaving the American film industry in 1930, EG moved temporarily to Washington, DC, before returning to London, where she spent the rest of her life. She said she returned simply because [t]here is no place like home, after all. Biographer Joan Hardwick, however, describes the move as motivated by her mother's recent stroke and by the fact that non-payment of tax had got her into trouble in the USA.326-7269

Though EG's novels and films generated a high income, her inability to manage her money kept her under continuous financial pressure. Failure to pay tax on her US income led to her being pursued for payment by the IRS. She died worth £6,588 11s. 1d.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: United Artists released the talking film that EG had produced and directed on her own, Knowing Men, at the Regal Cinema, Marble Arch, London.

SHORTPROSE.P: EG announced her intention to direct and produce this film in October 1929, provoking from Film Weekly the question, Can Women Direct Films?248 She did this work through the production company she had financed and established (at Elstree Studios with her business partner, Edward Knoblock) on her return to England. Knowing Men turned out to be the first and the last film she produced and released through her company. She had persuaded United Artists both to release it and to make an advance payment, but the film—which starred Elissa Landi, Carl Brisson, Helen Haye, and Jeanne de Casalis—was a critical failure. Embarrassed by the devastating reviews, Knoblock got a temporary block on the film. The result was that no profit, other than the initial advance, could be generated, and the film itself could not meet its release date.248-9270-1332-4under Elinor Glyn153
Herself undeterred, EG tried producing The Price of Things in 1930. The general public never saw this film, however, and she lost a great deal of money in the process.316-19272249
In all she spent £40,000 on her endeavours to break into the English film industry, which plunged her once again into financial difficulty.332

During the late 1920s and early 30s, EG was caught up in the wave of Spiritualism (the belief that the living can contact the dead through mediums) that had been gaining ground in England particularly since the First World War. For EG, Spiritualism and making contact the dead was a reality, as were the past lives she believed she had lived. These beliefs led her to assume that she possessed natural psychic powers, and I told myself that I ought to develop them.327 She argued that she could not see any religious or other reason which . . . precludes honest inquiry into the mass of strange phenomena.327 She joined a Spiritualist group and attended a number of séances (in which the dead were contacted through a medium); she also contacted spirits herself through mediums. I was convinced that there could be nothing faked about it . . . . There was no trickery of any ordinary kind, and the messages must, therefore, represent either genuine communications from the other side or else some form of telepathy between my own subconscious mind and that of the medium, she later wrote in her autobiography.328 EG also claimed to be able to do automatic writing, which occurs when a person writes at the behest of an external, unseen source. The writer has no control over what is written or what language the writing is in, hence, automatic. (George Yeats, wife of poet W. B. Yeats, is one of the best known practitioners of this kind of Spiritualist activity.)

Eventually, however, EG, having noted that the predictions of mediums seldom came true, lost her faith in Spiritualism and automatic writing. She was completely and finally convinced that these supposed communications from the dead, whether through mediums . . . or automatic writing, are entirely deceptive and wholly evil.329-30 Having renounced Spiritualism (which she did by 1934), she devised something new to believe about messages from the other side: that all supposed communications from the dead are really made by non-human sprite-like, dis-embodied entities.330

In 1931 EG visited Hungary, where she stayed with the Hungarian Minister in London, Baron Rubido-Zichy, and his wife. There she noted the continuance of a kind of feudal system, whose handling of class distinction she admired. The happy feudal relationship between landlord and peasant which exists still in Hungary is like that which used to prevail amongst the country squires and people of the English countryside, and the general atmosphere of mutual respect and of community interests is the same.316, 318
Such sentiments link her once again with Emmuska, Baroness Orczy.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: With earnings from her book sales, EG bought a good-sized flat in Connaught Place, Bayswater.

SHORTPROSE.P: She spent the last years of her life writing and travelling in the British Isles. By the time the second world war brought air raids back again to London, EG was living in a flat in Hertford House in Mayfair, which was paid for by an annuity given to her by her two daughters.xx

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: EG died at 39 Royal Avenue, Chelsea, after a week in hospital, from an undetermined illness.
